title: Girls 8, 9 and 10 found in polyamorous horror house with 245 animals living in faeces
text:

Three young girls and 245 animals have been found in 'deplorable living conditions', surrounded by urine and faeces.

Police also found a dead guinea pig and rotting food in the property in the city of Edgewater, Florida, where a polyamorous 'throuple' lived with the children aged 8,9 and 10.

Three people - Greg Nelson, 57, his wife Susan Nelson, 43 and his live-in girlfriend Melissa Hamilton, 49 - now face charges including three counts of child abuse and 66 counts of animal cruelty.

Police chief Joe Mahoney said the home was 'probably the worst house' he has ever been in.

(Image: City Of Edgewater Police Department)

(Image: City Of Edgewater Police Departm)

US media reports Mr Nelson had called police because he wanted to end his relationships with both women but they were refusing to allow him to take the children.

Ms Hamilton had 'threatened to kill herself' if he took them away, it is reported.

When officers attended found hundreds of animals of different species, including a tortoise; hedgehog; bearded dragon; two geckos; two cats; four hamsters; four dogs; nine guinea pigs; 10 sugar gliders; 12 rabbits; 14 birds; 60 rats; 23 rat pups and 95 mice.

(Image: City Of Edgewater Police Department)

(Image: City Of Edgewater Police Department)

A police spokesman said: "It was immediately evident neither the children, nor the animals were being cared for properly.

"The residence was in deplorable living conditions.

"EPD Officers observed a dead guinea pig in a cage, rotting food, animal feces and urine throughout the residence.

"The juveniles ages 8, 9 and 10 were removed from the residence by the Department of Children and Families and were placed with a responsible family member."

(Image: City Of Edgewater Police Departm)

(Image: City Of Edgewater Police Departm)

The animal were removed from the house and taken to the Edgewater Animal Shelter for further checks.

The shelter is taking domations to help care for the animals.

“I have been to many bad houses but that is probably the worst house I’ve ever entered,” Chief Mahoney told the Daytona Beach News-Journal.

“I felt bad for the little girls. It’s just sad.”

Greg Nelson is in EPD custody and Melissa Hamilton's whereabouts are known, but she is not in police custody at this time, the force added.

Monetary donations for the children can be made to the Edgewater Police Volunteers Association at the Police Department lobby.
description: Police were called out to the home in Florida by a man who wanted custody of the girls after breaking up with both his wife and his live-in girlfriend
